title: Jamkoriapur
text:
Jamkoriapur is a village in <a href="Khiron">Khiron</a> block of <a href="Rae%20Bareli%20district">Rae Bareli district</a>, <a href="Uttar%20Pradesh">Uttar Pradesh</a>, <a href="India">India</a>. It is located 21 km from <a href="Lalganj%2C%20Uttar%20Pradesh">Lalganj</a>, the tehsil headquarters. As of 2011, it has a population of 881 people, in 191 households. It has 1 primary school and no healthcare facilities and it hosts a weekly <a href="haat">haat</a> but not a permanent market. It belongs to the <a href="nyaya%20panchayat">nyaya panchayat</a> of <a href="Tikwamau%2C%20Raebareli">Tikwamau</a>.
The <a href="1951%20Census%20of%20India">1951 census</a> recorded Jamkoriapur as comprising 1 hamlet, with a total population of 221 people (112 male and 109 female), in 46 households and 43 physical houses. The area of the village was given as 347 <a href="acre">acre</a>s. 8 residents were literate, all male. The village was listed as belonging to the <a href="pargana">pargana</a> of Khiron and the <a href="thana">thana</a> of <a href="Gurbakshganj">Gurbakshganj</a>.
The <a href="1961%20Census%20of%20India">1961 census</a> recorded Jamkoriapur as comprising 1 hamlet, with a total population of 260 people (126 male and 134 female), in 53 households and 52 physical houses. The area of the village was given as 347 <a href="acre">acre</a>s.
The <a href="1981%20Census%20of%20India">1981 census</a> recorded Jamkoriapur as having a population of 424 people, in 81 households, and having an area of 148.93 <a href="hectare">hectare</a>s. The main staple foods were given as wheat and rice.
The <a href="1991%20Census%20of%20India">1991 census</a> recorded Jamkoriapur (as "Jam Koriyapur") as having a total population of 458 people (214 male and 244 female), in 95 households and 95 physical houses. The area of the village was listed as 149 hectares. Members of the 0-6 age group numbered 104, or 23% of the total; this group was 55% male (57) and 45% female (47). Members of <a href="scheduled%20castes">scheduled castes</a> made up 26% of the village's population, while no members of <a href="scheduled%20tribes">scheduled tribes</a> were recorded. The <a href="literacy%20rate">literacy rate</a> of the village was 17% (70 men and 9 women). 89 people were classified as main workers (77 men and 12 women), while 0 people were classified as marginal workers; the remaining 369 residents were non-workers. The breakdown of main workers by employment category was as follows: 57 cultivators (i.e. people who owned or leased their own land); 26 agricultural labourers (i.e. people who worked someone else's land in return for payment); 0 workers in livestock, forestry, fishing, hunting, plantations, orchards, etc.; 0 in mining and quarrying; 0 household industry workers; 0 workers employed in other <a href="manufacturing">manufacturing</a>, processing, service, and repair roles; 0 <a href="construction%20worker">construction worker</a>s; 0 employed in trade and commerce; 2 employed in transport, storage, and communications; and 4 in other services.
